questiontext.text: Which of these institutions already hosted a useR! conference?

generalfeedback.text:
The list of useR! (and DSC) hosts can be found at https://www.R-project.org/conferences/.

  1. True. useR! 2008 was hosted at TU Dortmund.
  2. False. Universität Wien did not host an R conference yet (only TU Wien and WU Wien).
  3. False. Københavns Universitet hosted DSC but not useR!.
  4. True. useR! 2010 was hosted at NIST.
  5. True. useR! 2009 was hosted at Agrocampus Ouest, Rennes.

feedback.text: True. useR! 2008 was hosted at TU Dortmund.
False. Universität Wien did not host an R conference yet (only TU Wien and WU Wien).
False. Københavns Universitet hosted DSC but not useR!.

answer.text: National Institute of Standards and Technology

feedback.text: True. useR! 2010 was hosted at NIST.
True. useR! 2009 was hosted at Agrocampus Ouest, Rennes.

questiontext.text: What is the derivative of \(f(x) = x^{2} e^{2.1 x}\), evaluated at \(x = 0.54\)?

generalfeedback.text: Using the product rule for \(f(x) = g(x) \cdot h(x)\), where \(g(x) := x^{2}\) and \(h(x) := e^{2.1 x}\), we obtain \[ \begin{aligned} f'(x) &= [g(x) \cdot h(x)]' = g'(x) \cdot h(x) + g(x) \cdot h'(x) \\ &= 2 x^{2 - 1} \cdot e^{2.1 x} + x^{2} \cdot e^{2.1 x} \cdot 2.1 \\ &= e^{2.1 x} \cdot(2 x^1 + 2.1 x^{2}) \\ &= e^{2.1 x} \cdot x^1 \cdot (2 + 2.1 x). \end{aligned} \] Evaluated at \(x = 0.54\), the answer is \[ e^{2.1 \cdot 0.54} \cdot 0.54^1 \cdot (2 + 2.1 \cdot 0.54) = 5.259963. \] Thus, rounded to two digits we have \(f'(0.54) = 5.26\).

questiontext.text:
The waiting time (in minutes) at the cashier of two supermarket chains with different cashier systems is compared. The following statistical test was performed:


    Two Sample t-test

data:  Waiting by Supermarket
t = -3.4985, df = 123, p-value = 0.000326
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is less than 0
95 percent confidence interval:
      -Inf -1.120364
sample estimates:
 mean in group Sparag mean in group Consumo 
             3.933431              6.062307

Which of the following statements are correct? (Significance level 5%)

generalfeedback.text:
1. True. The absolute value of the test statistic is equal to 3.498.
  2. True. The test aims at showing that the difference of means is smaller than 0.
  3. False. The p-value is equal to 0.000326.
  4. False. The test aims at showing that the alternative that the waiting time is shorter at Sparag than at Consumo.
  5. True. The test result is significant (\(p < 0.05\)) and hence the alternative is shown, that the difference of means are smaller than 0.

answer.text: The absolute value of the test statistic is larger than 1.96.

feedback.text: True. The absolute value of the test statistic is equal to 3.498.
True. The test aims at showing that the difference of means is smaller than 0.
False. The p-value is equal to 0.000326.

answer.text: The test shows that the waiting time is longer at Sparag than at Consumo.

feedback.text: False. The test aims at showing that the alternative that the waiting time is shorter at Sparag than at Consumo.

answer.text: The test shows that the waiting time is shorter at Sparag than at Consumo.

feedback.text: True. The test result is significant (\(p < 0.05\)) and hence the alternative is shown, that the difference of means are smaller than 0.

questiontext.text: What is the name of the R function for negative binomial regression?

generalfeedback.text: glm.nb is the R function for negative binomial regression. See ?glm.nb for the corresponding manual page.

questiontext.text:
It is suspected that a supplier systematically underfills 5 l canisters of detergent. The filled volumes are assumed to be normally distributed. A small sample of \(8\) canisters is measured exactly. This shows that the canisters contain on average \(4963\) ml. The sample variance \(s^2_{n-1}\) is equal to \(3327.5\).

Determine a \(99\%\) confidence interval for the average content of a canister (in ml).

  1. What is the lower confidence bound? {1:NUMERICAL:=4891.629:0.1~%50%4910.468:0.1#Normal-based instead of t-based interval; for small samples, intervals based on the normal approximation are too narrow.}
  2. What is the upper confidence bound? {1:NUMERICAL:=5034.371:0.1~%50%5015.532:0.1#Normal-based instead of t-based interval; for small samples, intervals based on the normal approximation are too narrow.}

generalfeedback.text:
The \(99\%\) confidence interval for the average content \(\mu\) in ml is given by: \[ \begin{aligned} & \left[\bar{y} \, - \, t_{n-1;0.995}\sqrt{\frac{s_{n-1}^2}{n}}, \; \bar{y} \, + \, t_{n-1;0.995}\sqrt{\frac{s_{n-1}^2}{n}}\right] \\ &= \left[ 4963 \, - \, 3.4995\sqrt{\frac{3327.5}{8}}, \; 4963 \, + \, 3.4995\sqrt{\frac{3327.5}{8}}\right] \\ &= \left[4891.629, \, 5034.371\right]. \end{aligned} \]

  1. The lower confidence bound is \(4891.629\).
  2. The upper confidence bound is \(5034.371\).
